description: Nigredo
The Blackening / The Darkening
Confronting the Shadow / The Dark Night of the Soul

Often experienced as a catalyst for major growth, particularly during the transition from the Gross-Reflecting Realm (conventional ego, levels 14-18) to the Subtle Realm (vision-logic, levels 20+). It represents the necessary breakdown of the old, rigid self-structure before a more integrated self can emerge.

To dissolve the unrefined, unconscious, and inflated ego structure (the Prima Materia) through a process of internal 'putrefaction'. This breaks down the persona (social mask) and confronts the practitioner with their repressed 'shadow' aspects, creating fertile, psychic ground for a more authentic self to be born.

A period of intense psychological distress. Common feelings include depression, chaos, loss of meaning, profound doubt, worthlessness, alienation, and despair. It can feel like one's world is falling apart because, on a psychic level, it is. This is the death of the old self.

The willingness to look at the parts of yourself you have denied, repressed, or projected onto others—without flinching. Acknowledge your anger, jealousy, fears, and perceived failings without judgment.
The fortitude to stay in the metaphorical 'fire' of this process, resisting the urge to numb out or distract yourself. It requires facing uncomfortable truths and emotions head-on.
Actively letting go of your old identity, beliefs, and attachments. It is the conscious 'death' of the ego's control, trusting that a more whole self will emerge from the ashes.
Holding your own suffering with kindness. Differentiating from self-pity, this is the act of providing yourself the same comfort and understanding you would offer a dear friend in pain.

Documenting your journey with specific prompts: 'What qualities in others irritate me the most?' (projections), 'When do I feel like a hypocrite?', 'What am I most afraid of people discovering about me?', 'Fantasize a dialogue with the 'dark' part of myself.'
Engaging with a trained therapist, particularly with a Jungian or transpersonal orientation, who understands the nature of spiritual crises and can provide a safe container for this volatile process.

Paying close attention to dreams, as they are direct communications from the unconscious. Look for recurring symbols, dark figures, or themes of death and decay, as these are often manifestations of the Nigredo process.
A Jungian technique of consciously engaging with figures from your unconscious (dreams, fantasies) in a waking state. This allows for a direct dialogue with your shadow aspects in a contained way.

Focus on grounding, introspection, and release. Poses like Balasana (Child's Pose) for surrender, Tadasana (Mountain Pose) for stability, and deep hip-openers like Kapotasana (Pigeon Pose) to release stored emotional tension.

Gyan Mudra (Mudra of Knowledge) to encourage deep insight and self-understanding. Abhaya Mudra (Mudra of Fearlessness) to cultivate the courage needed to face the darkness. Prithvi Mudra (Mudra of Earth) for grounding and stability.
Nadi Shodhana (Alternate Nostril Breathing) to calm the chaotic emotional state and balance the nervous system, providing moments of clarity and peace amidst the turmoil.

The 'whitening' or Albedo. The successful navigation of Nigredo does not eliminate the shadow but integrates it. The goal is to emerge from the darkness with a conscious awareness of your repressed aspects, leading to greater wholeness, humility, and authenticity. This integration is the foundation upon which a more enlightened consciousness can be built.
'One does not become enlightened by imagining figures of light, but by making the darkness conscious. The latter procedure, however, is disagreeable and therefore not popular.' - Carl Jung
Nigredo (The Blackening)
A crisis of transformation; the 'putrefaction' of the lower nature (Prakriti) when it resists the descending Divine Force and the emergence of the Psychic Being.

A critical period of transition, often from the ego-centric mental and vital consciousness (levels 12-18) towards the spiritual consciousness. It is the necessary breakdown of the ignorant, egoistic nature to prepare it for purification and transformation.

To reject all that is foreign to the Divine. It is a process of purifying the being from the ego, the desires of the vital nature, and the falsehoods of the mind, so that the inmost Psychic Being can come to the front to govern the nature and turn it wholly towards the Divine.

A period of intense inner struggle, confusion, and despair. This is the result of the ego's and lower nature's resistance to change, and the friction caused by the clash between the descending Light and the established habits of the Ignorance.

To be turned wholly to the Divine and accept only the Divine impulses. To allow no part of the being, not even the most external, to contradict the central aspiration or to hide behind doubts, confusions, and subterfuges.
The call of the being for higher things. It is the upward turning of the inner being with a call and yearning for the Divine Consciousness, Peace, Ananda, and the descent of the Divine Force.
The power to go through difficulty, trouble, and periods of darkness without getting depressed, discouraged, or impatient, and without giving up one's aim or resolution to reach the Divine.

To give everything one is or has to the Divine—regarding nothing as one's own. To obey only the Divine Will, rejecting the falsehood of the lower forces, and to live for the Divine and not for the ego.

The active refusal of all that is foreign to the Divine: rejecting the mind's habitual ideas and constructions, the vital nature's desires and impulses, and the physical nature's inertia and obscurity, so that the true knowledge may find free room.

A self-concentration inwards (towards the Psychic Being in the heart centre) or upwards (towards the higher Self above the head) to open the consciousness to the Divine Influence, Power, and Presence.

To stand back from the movements of the mind, life, and body; to become the Witness Purusha who observes the activities of Nature (Prakriti) without identifying with them, thus enabling detachment and mastery.
Poses that help establish a foundation of calm, peace, and equality (Samata) in the body and vital being, which is the necessary basis for withstanding the turmoil of this stage.

To reinforce the central attitudes of the sadhana: Abhaya Mudra for faith and fearlessness in the face of inner darkness, Prithvi Mudra for grounding and stability, and Anjali Mudra for surrender and self-offering.
To purify the vital nature (prana-shuddhi) and quiet the restlessness of the emotional and desire-mind, creating a calmer state in which the inner being can be more easily contacted.

Purification. The aim is not merely to overcome a psychological crisis, but to purify the instruments of the lower nature so they no longer obstruct the Divine's working. This allows the Psychic Being to emerge and guide the being toward a complete transformation of the nature into a vessel for the Divine.
The Divine Guidance leads the soul through both light and darkness, using all experiences for growth of being, even when not consciously recognised.
